analyzeResult.content:
TELEVISION 2 "CURRENT NEWS" 20.9.83
This is not a smoking room, but I really hold a cigarette in my hand.
This cigarette was launched in Finland in the beginning of September, but it has been a subject of controversy in USA and Europe for three years. The point in question is a new filter. This new filter may namely cheat both smoking machines and smokers as well. The measuring methods of the detrimental substances of cigarettes, the reliability of inspection certificates, the belief that light cigarettes are as a rule more healthy than stronger cigarettes are now questionable.
(KL)
The point of this controversy which has got so huge proportions is this: As medical scientists haveever more unquestionably proved the many health risks of smoking, there have been effortsall over the world to pass over to lighter cigarettes. There are three kinds of methods for this. First, manufacturers have used tobacco where tar, carbon monoxide and nicotine contents remain as low as possible when smoking a cigarette. The second method is to produce more and more porous cigarette papers so that it is possible to dilute the tobacco smoke with air. And the third method is to make small holes in the paper around the acetate filter through which the air comes directly into a filter and thus dilutes the smoke before it comes into a smoker's lungs.
The newest new in this ventilation technique of cigarette smoke is a filter - now available also in Finland - where there are four air channels that run the length of the filter. When marketing the new filter, it is praised for not only being well ventilated but also tasting better due to its aerodynamic.
The competitors do not agree at all. They consider the new filter as humbug; it is designed so that it is possible to cheat smoking machines in various countries. These machines - measuring detrimental substances in cigarettes - are quite similar everywhere.
And here we have one of those cheated, maybe. It is a chain smoker working permanently in The Food Research Laboratory of The State
699938195

paragraphs.content: This is not a smoking room, but I really hold a cigarette in my hand.

This cigarette was launched in Finland in the beginning of September, but it has been a subject of controversy in USA and Europe for three years. The point in question is a new filter. This new filter may namely cheat both smoking machines and smokers as well. The measuring methods of the detrimental substances of cigarettes, the reliability of inspection certificates, the belief that light cigarettes are as a rule more healthy than stronger cigarettes are now questionable.

The point of this controversy which has got so huge proportions is this: As medical scientists haveever more unquestionably proved the many health risks of smoking, there have been effortsall over the world to pass over to lighter cigarettes. There are three kinds of methods for this. First, manufacturers have used tobacco where tar, carbon monoxide and nicotine contents remain as low as possible when smoking a cigarette. The second method is to produce more and more porous cigarette papers so that it is possible to dilute the tobacco smoke with air. And the third method is to make small holes in the paper around the acetate filter through which the air comes directly into a filter and thus dilutes the smoke before it comes into a smoker's lungs.

The newest new in this ventilation technique of cigarette smoke is a filter - now available also in Finland - where there are four air channels that run the length of the filter. When marketing the new filter, it is praised for not only being well ventilated but also tasting better due to its aerodynamic.

The competitors do not agree at all. They consider the new filter as humbug; it is designed so that it is possible to cheat smoking machines in various countries. These machines - measuring detrimental substances in cigarettes - are quite similar everywhere.
And here we have one of those cheated, maybe. It is a chain smoker working permanently in The Food Research Laboratory of The State
